docs.lead_paragraph: To The Living Section: After reading Molly O'Neill's piece on the conflict between gourmets and nutritionists, "Grocery Wars: Good-for-You vs. Indulge!" [ Feb. 26 ] , I thought it unfortunate that my colleagues, the gourmets, sounded so irrational, defensive and uninformed.

docs.lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY THIS resort has been called many things, but never, even in the pre-gambling casino era, had it ever been called, a gourmet capital. Now, however, a few residents have formed a chapter of the Chaine des Rotisseurs, the Paris-based society that caters to some of the world's most cultivated taste buds. ''This is something the casinos have brought to this city,'' said Patrick McGahn, a local lawyer, at the chapter's second formal dinner last Sunday night. ''It is opening new vistas and uplifting the quality of life here.''

docs.abstract: The markets in Paris are just beginning to offer the local ingredients that making cooking so satisfying.
docs.lead_paragraph: These days, one thing food-loving and restaurant people make a big deal about here is "cuisine du marché," which translates roughly as "cooking from the market." We have restaurants like that too, of course, places where the chef (or his or her representative) buys what he or she sees and cooks it for dinner. Nice idea, though you could also call it traditional home cooking, as long as things don't get too fancy.
docs.snippet: The markets in Paris are just beginning to offer the local ingredients that making cooking so satisfying....

docs.abstract: Stacy Jannis and Helen Feit letters on Mark Bittman's September 24 travel article on Lucca, Italy, and its cuisine; photo
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''The Riches of Lucca'' (Sept. 24) by Mark Bittman, along with the glorious photography spread by Chris Warde-Jones, brought back vivid memories of a summer spent there 30 years ago. As an 18-year-old art student, I lived with a group in the city -- somewhat counterculturally -- on one floor of the dilapidated and, at the time, ''condemned to the public'' Palazzo Guinigi, for six weeks. Back then, the most frequently used pickup line was a variation of ''Come with me to Viareggio,'' where the scene was ''happening'' but the food was invariably not that great.

docs.abstract: Review of year's notable ideas and developments notes growing variety of foods, soups and beverages being put in car cup-holders so people can eat while they drive; 7-Eleven polls carmakers and finds that many vehicles have more cup holders than passengers; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The car cup holder has been colonized. No longer just a slot for a coffee or Diet Coke, the crater in the console can now contain a wide selection of foods for breakfast, junk and dinner, all in cup-contained portions that let you eat while you drive. In April, Frito-Lay launched Go Snacks, plastic canisters filled with 3-D Doritos, Cheetos or Fritos Hoops. ''Before, it was just drinks,'' says Lynn Markley, a Frito-Lay spokesperson. ''And we thought, Why can't we be in there next to the Pepsi can? There are two cup holders.'' Or more than two: 7-Eleven polled carmakers and found that many vehicles have more cup holders than passengers (some minivans have 16). With this in mind, in May the company rolled out the Candy Gulp, a plastic cup filled with gummy animals. It sits alongside Nabisco Go-Packs -- small, resealable bins of crackers and cookies -- and handsize cups from Hershey's filled with Reese's Bites and Kit Kat Bites.

docs.abstract: Joanne Starkey reviews Camille's restaurant in Carle Place, Long Island; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ''HELLO, you've reached Camille's fine Continental restaurant . . . '' the recording says at this Carle Place newcomer. What, a 1999 restaurant describing itself as Continental? In recent years that passe label has become a negative one, calling to mind snooty service and fussy, over-sauced food. Camille's does not fit that stereotype. Service is friendly and casual, and the food lighter than expected. An appetizer of four seared sea scallops on a bed of sauteed spinach with a warm saffron vinaigrette is a prime example. It is also the most successful opener.

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether to be deplored or celebrated, the current interest in food, and the much-heralded culinary revolution we are supposed to be in the midst of, are hardly new phenomena. Throughout recorded history there have been fashions in food, however primitive or refined. Connoisseurship probably began with the first person who noticed that apples from one tree tasted just a little better than those from another, or with the first caveman who decided that meat had a more pleasant flavor when roasted over hickory wood instead of pine. Once esthetic differences were recognized, everything else that has happened in cuisine followed almost inevitably. ''Everything else,'' in this case, includes all of the food snobbisms that have cropped up in various times and places, competition between chefs, the worldwide search for the best and most exotic products, and even food critics whose true function is, at best, to guide the public in making choices.
